Award.AwardTitle: Integration of Odor Stimulus Features during Olfactory Processing
Award.AbstractNarration: Airborne chemicals (odors) present in the environment provide a valuable source of information for animals about the suitability of food, potential mates and habitats, as well as threats such as the presence of predators. The olfactory system equips animals with the ability to detect and assess the chemical nature of their surroundings and adjust their behavior appropriately. Single odors are often complex chemical mixtures that occur together because they are released from a defined source. However, a single odor does not occur in isolation--it is intermingled with other odors in the background. This project seeks to understand the mechanisms by which the brain picks out and recognizes individual odors against a noisy backdrop. Recordings will be made from single neurons in the olfactory centers of the moth brain while manipulating the presentation of odors to the antenna (nose) of the insect. The results will provide new insights about the mechanisms by which odor information is represented by the brain and how this contributes to the recognition of complex odors as cohesive 'objects'. In addition to contributing to the basic understanding of how the sense of smell works, it is also expected that the use of pest insects, as the study system, may provide novel insights useful to the agricultural community in monitoring or disrupting insect behavior. Insects are excellent tools for introducing and engaging K-12 school children in the scientific process and such appropriate activities will form a part of the current project. High school students and undergraduates will also participate in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Male moths are highly attracted to female odors (pheromones) and can fly over large distances to locate a potential mate. The combination of predictable  behavior and well characterized odors makes moths an attractive and relatively simple system in which to study how the brain functions in detecting, processing and responding to odor stimuli.

Pheromones are detected by the moth nose (= antenna). Sensory neurons on the antenna are tuned to the female pheromones and react to them by sending signals to the brain. These signals are initially processed in a structure similar to the human olfactory bulb called the antennal lobe where sensory neurons communicate with other central neurons that then convey signals to higher brain centers. There are several types of central neuron and the goal of this project was to investigate how these different neuron types react to stimulation with odors and identify their targets in the central brain. Responses were recorded from individual neurons and a fluorescent dye was then injected into each cell so that neuron structure could be visualized under a microscope. Our results revealed that a poorly understood group of these neurons were best stimulated by the presence of a pheromone blend (female pheromones, like many odors, are often a specific mixture of different compounds that elicit optimal flight responses in males) and followed pulses of the stimulus more accurately when compared to single compounds alone. In addition, when these integrative, blend neurons were stained with fluorescent dye they were shown to follow pathways that reached several different target areas in the brain. Combining information from different sensory pathways is a critical aspect of the brain's function in making appropriate behavioral decisions. Some of the target areas we identified also receive information from other sensory structures such as the eyes and visual input is critical for insect flight. Our results provided new insights into how sensory systems integrate odor stimulus features such as the presence of an appropriate blend and potential areas of the brain where information across senses converges. The results of our work provide a framework for future studies in this area.

As is typical, results generated by the project have been reported to the scientific community through publications and presentations at conferences. More broadly, during the course of this project several undergraduate students had the opportunity to participate on specific aspects of the research and present results of their work at undergraduate symposia. Most have now gone on to professional careers (medicine, nursing) or graduate school. Additionally, two postdoctoral researchers and technicians received training in the laboratory. The principal investigator also initiated a series of talks given by Biology alumni to provide current undergraduates with insights into interesting or unusual career paths they have taken. Outreach to the public included several workshops organized for high school students with interest in pursuing science degrees at University as well as other presentations. Lab personnel frequently participated in judging at local high school science fairs.
